I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2005 County Strategy and Program Mission, the Government of Uzbekistan 
confirmed its request to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance (TA) to 
prepare the Development of Market Infrastructure for Private Farms and Agribusinesses Project. 
A Fact-Finding Mission visited Uzbekistan during 17–25 August 2005 and held discussions with 
officials and representatives from the Cabinet of Ministers, the Ministry of Agriculture and Water 
Resources, the Ministry of Economy, the Ministry of Finance, the Association of Dekhan Farms, 
the Businesswomen’s Association, and the research institutes involved in fruit and vegetables 
and several farmers. The mission reached agreement with the Government on the objectives, 
design and monitoring framework, methodology, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, 
and financing. The TA is included in ADB’s 2005 program. 1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Historically, agriculture has been the engine of growth in Uzbekistan’s economy, and 
currently contributes more than 25% the country’s gross domestic product, about a third of total 
national employment, and half of total export earnings. Cotton is the primary export crop and 
foreign  exchange  revenue  earner,  and  wheat  production  assures  food  self-sufficiency. 
Uzbekistan continues to be one of the major suppliers of fresh and processed fruit, vegetables, 
meat, and wool to its neighbors while also providing bountiful quantities to the domestic market, 
although export sales of these products are currently sporadic and flat and go primarily to 
buyers from Kazakhstan, Russian Federation, and Turkey. In the early 1990s, Uzbekistan was 
the largest producer of fruit and vegetables in the former Soviet Union; however, its increased 
dependence  on  cotton  exports  and  revenue  led  to  a  loss  of  comparative  advantage  in 
horticulture crops. There is scope for increasing the yields and productivity of horticulture crops 
on private plots. Livestock and fodder are produced for the domestic market on a limited scale. 
3.  Following independence, the Government made significant changes in the agriculture 
sector. Reforms centered on dismantling the large state farms and introducing shirkat collective 
farms (5,000 hectares or less) and private family farms (10–250 hectares). Family farms already 
dominate Uzbek agriculture: in 2005, Uzbekistan had about 125,000 private family farms. The 
Government has been disappointed with the performance of the shirkat farms and is downsizing 
most of them to the level of family farms. The downsizing is scheduled to be completed in 2007, 
leaving only about 820 nationwide. The Government has also expanded its program of dekhan 
or household farms, which are basically household gardens that are part of family farms and 
shirtkats. Dekhan farms are extremely small (0.17–0.37 hectares), but manage to contribute 
significantly to total agricultural output and account for some 90% of livestock output. Dekhan 
farmers are free to grow what they want and sell their production at full market prices. Some of 
the shirkats and private family farms that are adjacent to urban centers do not cultivate cotton 
and wheat, but instead produce higher-value fruit and vegetables and raise livestock largely for 
urban consumers. More than 6,000 family farms are specialized horticulture farms. Private 
family farms are marginally profitable, averaging SUM8,000 per hectare, because of their lower 
than shirkats production costs and their relatively greater freedom to cultivate and sell other 
crops on the remaining 10–20% of lands that are not dedicated to cotton and wheat. Dekhan 
plots effectively demonstrate the potential for high-value crop production. Estimates indicate that 
if given the opportunity, farmers’ incomes from fruit and vegetables could be triple those derived 
from cotton and wheat.2

4.  Because of the strategic roles that cotton and wheat play in generating public revenues 
and in ensuring self-sufficiency in food, the Government is heavily involved in the upstream and 
downstream value chains for these crops. At the farm level, farmers’ production agreements 
with processors’ associations specify the cropping pattern, the volume of production, the areas 
devoted to cotton and wheat production, and the prices received for these commodities. Input 
production, supplies of farm machinery, service provision, irrigation water and services, and 
processing and marketing for cotton and wheat are run predominantly by Government-owned 
enterprises. The Government also provides subsidized credit in support of quotas for these 
crops. For cotton and wheat, the main impetus to growth in production will be a shift in the policy 
environment. Reforms have begun under three ongoing ADB-financed projects,3 with quota 
reductions and a dual pricing approach (procurement price for the quota production that is tied 
to world market prices and a higher procurement price for nonquota production). These reforms 
are being extended under the proposed Land Improvement Project, to be approved by ADB in 
2006, with quota reductions, improved pricing policies, restrictions on the influence of local 
government  officials  in  production  and  marketing  decisions,  expanded  land  tenure  with 
registered and transferable land titles, and improved credit access from commercial banks. The 
Agriculture  Sector  Project,  proposed  for  2008,  is  expected  to  further  deepen  reforms  and 
liberalize the production and marketing of cotton and wheat. 
5.  To a large extent, horticulture and livestock production functions within the framework of 
a free market economy. The Government interferes little and provides limited research and 
extension services. Horticulture and livestock inputs are usually available at reasonable prices. 
The production is sold either directly through local markets for fresh products or to small private 
enterprises specializing in fruit, vegetable, meat, wool, and leather processing. Processing 
facilities  are  poor  and  limited,  and  there  is  large  scope  for  improvement  using  private 
investment. In this context, market infrastructure includes agricultural input and output supply 
systems using wholesale, retail, and assembly markets; storage facilities; packaging and cold 
storage facilities; transport, including refrigerated trucks; processing plants; and postharvest 
handling facilities. These are largely considered to be private infrastructure goods. 
6.  Fruit  and  vegetable  products,  both  raw  and  processed,  have  the  potential  to  grow 
significantly  in  relation  to  both  domestic  and  export  markets  through  increased  private 
investment  and  technology  transfer,  thereby  accelerating  development  in  horticulture  and 
agribusiness. Demand for better quality and larger quantities of fresh and processed fruit and 
vegetables is expected to increase because of the gradual change in the population’s tastes 
and preferences and because of expanded incomes and employment opportunities. The time is 
right  for  expanded  support  to  horticulture  producers  and  small-scale,  private  agribusiness 
entrepreneurs.  Fruit  and  vegetable  farmers  and  processors  require  an  integrated  market 
approach that will assure market access; technology training; good quality planting materials; 
farm management improvements; improved cultivation practices; appropriate machinery; and 
farmer-based  and  commercial  organizations  with  links  to  the  private  sector,  including 
consumers and supermarkets in Uzbekistan and in other countries. Agribusiness processors 
and wholesalers will benefit from capacity building through hands-on training and access to

updated infrastructure. Even though Uzbekistan has a large number of entrepreneurs at all 
levels, they clearly need assistance with business planning and administration and product 
development.  Enterprise  managers,  family-owned  businesses,  and  staff  require  better 
understanding of the functions of an enterprise and how to develop realistic business plans. 
There is also a need for the TA to explore (i) financial mechanisms that enable agribusinesses 
to  access  credit;4  (ii)  measures  for  providing  agricultural  support  services  and  market 
information  and  communication  technologies  to  private  producers,  entrepreneurs,  and 
marketing agents; and (iii) institutional linkages, such as involvement in agribusiness support by 
the  Association  of  Dekhan  Farms,  businesswomen’s  associations,  and  the  Chamber  of 
Commerce.   
7.  ADB’s strategy in the sector is to promote sustainable, employment-generating growth 
and to accelerate rural development by providing support for a diversified, productive, and 
sustainable rural sector to create rural jobs and raise rural incomes. The Government and ADB 
agree that looking beyond agriculture at key aspects of rural development (rural services, 
infrastructure,  and  environmental  management)  in  a  holistic  way  is  important.  The  donor 
community is beginning to provide access to market infrastructure for private farmers and 
agribusinesses on a limited scale,. The World Bank’s Rural Enterprise Support Project has a 
rural finance component that onlends working capital and investment funds to private farms and 
rural business enterprises. The International Finance Corporation is providing technical support 
and a special credit facility for the creation and development of leasing as a medium-term 
financial instrument for the procurement of machinery, equipment, vehicles, and so on. The 
European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has started to provide working capital to 
two agro-enterprises that produce and export dried and concentrated fruit and vegetables. The 
United Nations Center for Trade and Development and the World Trade Organization are 
providing assistance to facilitate trade in agricultural products and equipment by publishing 
demand forecasts and import requirements. These external financing agencies estimate that 
demand for horticulture products in local and foreign markets is large. 
8.  The lessons learned from these experiences are (i) that demand from private farms and 
private agribusinesses for market infrastructure facilities is large; (ii) that the agriculture sector 
can take advantage of diverse local and foreign markets; (iii) that incentives are required for 
private investment, which is needed to ensure that private farmers and entrepreneurs are on a 
par with their trading rivals in other countries; and (iv) that access to and development of 
privately-run financial mechanisms and contractual arrangements that foster vertical alliances 
among strategic players in the value chain are equally important. The TA will build on the 
lessons learned by the Government and the donor community from previous and ongoing 
agriculture-based project investments in Uzbekistan and other countries. The TA will include a 
value chain analysis to identify existing financial services for small-scale private agribusinesses 
that can provide business plans that can clearly justify a viable return on investment.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  Project’s  impact  will  be  to  ensure  the  profitability  of  private  farms  and 
agribusinesses by providing market infrastructure for horticulture. The project preparatory TA’s 
outcome will be a feasibility study of the agreed methodology, activities, and implementation 
and financing arrangements for an investment project. Appendix 1 provides the design and 
monitoring framework.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The scope of the TA is to carry out a feasibility study that will determine the investments 
in market infrastructure that will directly benefit private farms and agribusinesses by increasing 
productivity and improving incomes and profitability by diversifying to high-valued crops, making 
intensive use of input resources, and adding value to farm produce through further processing 
and/or expansion of market outlets. The TA will be conducted in two phases: phase 1, a 
diagnostic  phase  comprising  an  analysis  of  the  current  situation,  including  a  value  chain 
analysis of key horticulture products, and phase 2, a prescriptive phase that proposes options 
and recommendations for an investment project. The TA will have three major outputs. The first 
is a comprehensive assessment of (i) the marketing arrangements for major cash crops (fruit 
and vegetables) to determine key market infrastructure needs; (ii) the training and capacity gaps 
among  those  working  at  private  farms  and  agribusinesses,  as  well  as  an  analysis  of  the 
strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats pertaining to institutions and of contractual 
and other arrangements that, if provided, would complement market infrastructure investments 
by enhancing the integration of private farms with the value chain; and (iii) the socioeconomic 
and environmental conditions of farms producing and marketing cash crops. This output will 
determine the options for market infrastructure investment that could potentially be financed by 
the Project. The second output of the TA will be a technical, economic, financial, and socio-
environmental appraisal of investment options that also identifies the project components. This 
appraisal will include an analysis of the value chain to identify bottlenecks, stakeholder analysis 
to ascertain the distribution of costs and benefits, and a budget analysis of sample enterprises 
to show how interventions can reduce costs and improve financial and economic performance. 
The third output is detailed cost estimates, a financing plan, and implementation arrangements. 
11.  Key activities include (i) establishing a database and developing the market demand and 
supply  analysis  for  the  cash  crops;  (ii)  determining  the  priority  market  infrastructure 
requirements for the value chain of cash crops; (iii) identifying the capacity-building needs of 
private farms and agribusinesses in relation to the market infrastructure options as well as the 
contractual and/or institutional arrangements that will better align them with the value chain; (iv) 
determining the financial mechanisms and arrangements for accessing the market infrastructure 
developed through the Project; (v) preparing the technical, financial, economic, and socio-
environmental analyses using with and without project scenarios; (vi) validating the project 
design  through  periodic  consultation  meetings  with  representative  stakeholders;  and 
(vii) detailing  the  costs  and  financing  mechanisms  of  the  Project,  identifying  the  risks  and 
assumptions, and determining the appropriate management and monitoring systems that will 
ensure efficient and effective implementation of the Project. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the ADB TA grant is estimated to be $850,000 equivalent, to be 
financed by ADB’s TA funding program. It is proposed that ADB finance $600,000 equivalent.

5
The Government will provide $250,000 equivalent in in-kind counterpart costs and services.5 
The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates are given in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The  Executing  Agency  will  be  the  Rural  Restructuring  Agency  of  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture and Water Resources. Overall supervision and coordination within the Government 
will be the responsibility of the Information and Analytical Department on Agriculture Industry 
and Water Economy of the Cabinet of Ministers. The TA will be carried out over 5 months, 
commencing in January 2006 and ending in June 2006. A total of 46.5 person-months of 
individual consulting services will be required: 18.5 international and 28.0 domestic. Some of the 
time  has  not  been  allocated  to  specific  specialists  to  accommodate  needs  for  additional 
expertise identified during the study or extensions of some members of the consulting team, if 
required. The international consultants will have expertise in agribusiness marketing, agricultural 
economics, financial analysis, and environmental assessment. The domestic consultants will 
have expertise in institutional and social assessment, horticulture crops, agroprocessing, farm 
machinery, and legal issues. The outline terms of reference for consulting services are in 
Appendix 3. ADB will engage individual consultants in accordance with the Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. The consultants will procure equipment 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
14.  At the end of the first month following commencement of the TA, the consultant team will 
submit an inception report to the Rural Restructuring Agency and ADB that will be discussed in 
a tripartite review meeting and at a stakeholder workshop. In the third month, the team will 
submit a draft midterm report to the Rural Restructuring Agency and ADB that will include 
preliminary findings of the assessment of various project components. The midterm report will 
incorporate suggestions raised during the first stakeholder workshop and will culminate in a 
second tripartite review meeting in the third month. At the end of the fourth month, a draft final 
report will be submitted to the Rural Restructuring Agency and ADB and will be presented by 
the consultants at a second stakeholder workshop. A third tripartite review meeting will also be 
held to discuss the draft final report. The suggestions from the stakeholder workshops and the 
third  tripartite  review  meeting  will  be  incorporated  into  the  final  report.  All  reports  will  be 
submitted in both English and Russian. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Uzbekistan  for  preparing  the  Development  of  Market  Infrastructure  for 
Private Farms and Agribusinesses Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
5  The Government will (i) provide an office with furniture and fixtures for use by the team of consultants; (ii) pay for 
utilities (heating and electricity) for the office; (iii) ensure access to telephone service; (iv) pay for the remuneration, 
per diem, and transportation expenses of the Government’s counterpart staff assigned to the TA; and (v) provide 
the team with access to the Government’s data, maps, survey results, and other documents.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Team Leader/Agribusiness Marketing Specialist (international, 5 person-months) 
1.  The team leader will have a degree in economics, agribusiness development, or a 
related  field;  at  least  20  years  of  work  experience  in  designing  and  managing  agriculture 
development projects from a value chain system approach; and work experience in transition 
economies,  particularly  in  Central  Asia  and  Uzbekistan.  The  responsibilities  include  the 
following: 
(i)  Take the lead in formulating and developing the design and the feasibility study 
for  the  Project,  including  (a)  a  comprehensive  market  analysis  for  major 
commodities,  capacity  building,  and  institutional,  social,  and  environmental 
assessments;  (b)  a  rigorous  technical,  economic,  financial,  social,  and 
environmental evaluation of the investment and financing options and the project 
components;  and  (c)  a  design  for  the  financial  plan  and  appropriate 
implementation arrangements for the Project.  
(ii)  Conduct a market supply and demand analysis taking into account agronomic, 
policy, and institutional constraints as well as best global practices in integrating 
newly formed private farms into the value added chain by means of access to 
market infrastructure.  
(iii)  Determine the appropriate quantitative and qualitative methods for analysis and 
develop a work plan to ensure the satisfactory completion of the outputs of the 
technical assistance (TA).  
(iv)  Identify policy, pricing, and regulatory measures that will complement the Project 
and enhance the development of private sector agribusiness enterprises. With 
the assistance of the deputy team leader and the agricultural economist, analyze 
policy and institutional issues and constraints. 
(v)  Conduct a thorough analysis of commodity flows in the value chain, including 
current market locations; anticipated changes in the market with and without the 
Project; major bottlenecks to market penetration, such as transport, storage, 
roads, and relative efficiency levels from farms to markets; wastage occurring 
along the market chain; impact of current bureaucratic arrangements on markets; 
relevant pricing policies; marketing margins and product quality variants; quality 
to cost margins and distribution aspects; primary participants in the value chain 
(that is, are they self employed, underemployed, or fully employed, their skill 
levels and training needs, and the extent to which poverty factors into making 
people likely participants in the Project).  
(vi)  Recommend methodologies that will provide newly formed private farms with the 
access and knowledge to participate profitably in the Project.  
(vii)  Assess  current  crop  production  technologies  and  postharvest  handling 
procedures.  
(viii)  Determine  the  level  of  business  planning  and  identify  appropriate  training 
approaches to improve business planning.  
(ix)  Identify cofinancing options for capacity building and other technical support that 
will complement the project components. 
(x)  Ensure that major stakeholders are involved in the design and implementation 
phases of the Project. 
(xi)  Ensure the timely delivery of high-quality TA reports to the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) and the Rural Restructuring Agency.

2.  Agricultural Economist (international, 5 person-months) 
 
2.  The  agricultural  economist  will  have  a  graduate  degree  in  economics,  agricultural 
economics, or a closely related field and at least 10 years of work experience in the design and 
economic analysis of development projects and cost-benefit analysis in a value added chain 
approach. The agricultural economist will examine the economic viability and sustainability of 
the Project’s components and subprojects. The tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Conduct the economic analysis. Identify the with and without project lending 
scenarios and identify project alternatives to develop the basis for counterfactual 
analysis  and  cost-benefit  analysis  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on

(ii)  Identify the policy, pricing, and regulatory measures that will complement the 
subprojects and enhance the net benefits to society. 
(iii)  Provide inputs into the market, capacity building, and institutional assessments

3.  Financial Analyst/Financial Management Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
3.  The financial analyst should have a degree in business administration or accounting and 
at least 10 years of work experience in financial analysis, financial management assessments of 
development projects, and design and implementation of various rural finance mechanisms and 
measures;  and  extensive  knowledge  of  financial  management  operations  in  Uzbekistan. 
Specific tasks include the following: 
(i)  Ensure  consistency  in  approach,  methodology,  and  basic  assumptions  in 
coordination with the agricultural economist and carry out financial evaluations of 
the subprojects and project and assess their financial sustainability. 
(ii)  Prepare project cost estimates, the financing plan, and financial projections or 
other suitable software and assess the veracity of government counterparts, 
beneficiary contributions, and cofinancing, where applicable, in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment 
Projects. 
(iii)  Undertake  a  financial  management  assessment  of  the  Rural  Restructuring 
Agency and the Project Management Office, which should include a review of 
corporate planning and budgetary control, financial and management accounting, 
cost accounting, internal control and audit systems, and data processing. Provide 
a summary of the assessment that includes an evaluation of the adequacy of the 
agency’s financial management arrangements for project implementation and 
operation,  identifies  financial  management  risks,  and  suggests  mitigating 
measures. 
(iv)  Determine financial reporting mechanisms, requirements, and timetables as well 
as appropriate procurement, disbursement, and auditing arrangements that are 
in accordance with ADB guidelines. 
(v)  Provide inputs into the market, capacity building, and institutional assessments 
and prepare the financing plan and project implementation arrangements.

4.  Environment Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
4.  The environment specialist should have a graduate degree in environmental science or 
related socioeconomic academic credentials and at least 10 years of experience in dealing with 
social and environmental issues, preferably including experience in Uzbekistan. The specific 
tasks include the following: 
(i)  Conduct a socio-environmental assessment of representative components and 
subprojects for various commodities and farm and agribusiness types for this 
category C project. Use ADB environmental assessment guidelines and social 
and poverty analysis guidelines. 
(ii)  Help  the  agricultural  economist  and  the  team  leader  evaluate  the  socio-
environmental impact of projects components. 
(iii)  Examine current environmental conditions and the impact, if any, on current 
development of private agribusiness enterprises. 
 
5.  Deputy Team Leader/Institutional and Social Expert (domestic, 5 person-months) 
 
5.  The deputy team leader should have a graduate degree in institutional economics, 
development economics, or a related field and should have at least 10 years of work experience 
in dealing with institutional and social issues in project design and implementation. Specific 
tasks include the following: 
(i)  Evaluate  existing  institutional  and  contractual  arrangements  for  crops  by 
conducting an analysis of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats in 
relation to key stakeholders and institutions. 
(ii)  Oversee stakeholder consultations so that they provide effective feedback on 
project design.  
(iii)  Help liaise with public and private stakeholders to facilitate TA implementation 
and provide inputs into the implementation arrangements for the Project. 
(iv)  Conduct a social assessment and gender analysis for representative subproject 
market  infrastructure  investments  for  various  commodities  and  farm  and 
agribusiness types. Use ADB guidelines on social and poverty analysis. 
(v)  Help the agricultural economist and team leader conduct a policy and institutional 
analysis and evaluate the social impact of project components. 
(vi)  Coordinate administration of the TA and coordinate with ADB and the Rural 
Restructuring Agency in the absence of the team leader.

6.  Experts in Horticulture Crops and Processing (3 domestic, 3 person-months each) 
 
6.  Each expert should have the appropriate academic background for the specified crop 
(fruit and vegetables) or processing work and at least 10 years of work experience in the field of 
expertise. Each expert will have the following tasks: 
(i)  Assess  current  agronomic  and  technical  practices  for  the  major  crops  or 
processed products and cultural practices and identify technical constraints. 
(ii)  Help the team leader determine the technically desirable market infrastructure 
needs for these commodities or processed products that would intensify resource 
use, minimize production costs, and improve yields. 
(iii)  Provide  the  technical  data  and  help  the  finance  specialist  and  agricultural 
economist  with  their  respective  analyses  for  the  with  and  without  project 
scenarios. 
(iv)  Provide inputs into the market and institutional assessments and help identify 
capacity-building requirements. 
 
7.  Farm Machinery Expert (domestic, 3 person-months) 
 
7.  The farm machinery expert should have a graduate degree in agriculture engineering or 
a related field and at least 10 years of work experience with farm machinery for different 
agricultural commodities. The expert will have the following tasks: 
(i)  Evaluate current farm machinery in terms of usage, availability, and practices of 
different farms under different agronomic conditions together with the technical 
experts in horticulture crops and processing. 
(ii)  Determine  farm  machinery  requirements  suitable  for  the  commodity  and 
agronomic conditions of farms. Provide technical specifications for appropriate 
farm machinery and equipment. 
(iii)  Provide the technical data and assist the financial specialist and agricultural 
economist  with  their  respective  analyses  for  the  with  and  without  project 
scenarios. 
(iv)  Provide inputs into the market and institutional assessments and help identify 
capacity-building requirements. 
 
8.  Legal Expert (domestic, 3 person-months) 
 
8.  The legal expert should have a graduate degree in commercial law and at least 10 years 
of work experience as a lawyer. The expert should have strong knowledge of reforms in the 
agriculture sector and commercial legal instruments in relation to contractual agreements and 
financial mechanisms and arrangements. The expert will have the following tasks: 
(i)  Analyze different contractual arrangements and financial instruments that would 
vertically integrate private farms with downstream and upstream players and 
provide  access  to  market  infrastructure  together  with  the  team  leader  and 
financial analyst. 
(ii)  Identify appropriate contractual agreements and other legal measures that will 
facilitate farmers’ and agribusiness entrepreneurs’ access to inputs, postharvest 
handling facilities, storage, transportation, logistics, and foreign market outlets. 
(iii)  Develop legal templates for contractual agreements for linking private farms to 
their downstream and/or upstream partners, as well as for employing various 
financial mechanisms and arrangements.
